column2: HAWAII DMV PERMIT PRACTICE TEST
column4: Hawaii
column6: HI

column2: Question Text
column4: Answer1 Text
column6: Answer2 Text
column8: Answer3 Text

column2: 1. Where must you position your vehicle when you prepare to make a left turn from a two-way roadway into a one-way roadway?
column4: On the right curb.
column6: As close as possible to the center line.
column8: As far to the right as possible.

column2: 2. When driving in icy or snowy conditions, to avoid crashes drivers should:
column4: get off the highway as quickly as possible.
column6: reduce speed and increase following distance.
column8: engage 4 wheel drive on the vehicle.
column10: add extra weight to the vehicle to improve traction.

column2: 3. The shape of a route sign tells you:
column4: the type of route you are on.
column6: the speed limit on that route.
column8: that the route you are on might be dangerous.
column10: how many miles are left before you reach your destination.

column2: 4. When following motorcycles, drivers should:
column4: try to pass them as they have different braking capabilities than other motor vehicles.
column6: keep less space in front of their vehicle.
column8: reduce the minimum following distance.
column10: keep more space in front of their vehicle.

column2: 5. This road sign means:
column4: Hill ahead
column6: Trucks merging from the right
column8: Side road ahead

column2: 6. A thumping sound can be a warning:
column4: that a tire blowout is about to occur.
column6: of a brake failure.
column8: of a headlight failure.

column2: 7. This road sign:
column4: is a no-right-turns sign.
column6: warns drivers of a sharp turn left. Drivers should slow their speed and keep to the left.
column8: warns drivers that U-turns are not permitted.
column10: provides an advance notice of a roundabout.

column2: 8. You hear a siren close by but can not see where the emergency vehicle is. What do you do?
column4: Keep driving until you are sure the emergency vehicle is headed toward you.
column6: Pull over to the right side of the road and stop until you are sure the emergency vehicle is not headed toward you.
column8: Stop only if you are sure that the vehicle is headed toward you in the opposite lane.
column10: Stop immediately and activate your emergency flashers.

column2: 9. Night driving can be more difficult because:
column4: speed limits do not apply at night.
column6: visibility is reduced.
column8: vehicle operators tend to drive faster at night.
column10: the ratio of motorcyles to cars is much higher at night.

column2: 10. More than one vehicle is approaching a four-way stop sign. Who has the right of way?
column4: The first driver to reach the intersection and stop.
column6: The driver on the left.
column8: No one.
column10: The last driver to reach the intersection.

column2: 11. This road sign means:
column4: One-way traffic
column6: Do not pass trucks
column8: No trucks allowed

column2: 12. When in a motor vehicle on a highway, it is:
column4: permissible to drink a moderate amount of alcohol when driving with a passenger.
column6: illegal to drink from, but permissible to transport, open containers of alcohol in the passenger compartment.
column8: illegal to possess an open container of alcohol in the passenger compartment.
column10: acceptable to drink alcoholic beverages if you are not driving.

column2: 13. Arrows on the roadway:
column4: indicate HOV lanes.
column6: show which lanes you must use.
column8: indicate that you can not pass or change lanes.

column2: 14. ___________ are green with white letters and symbols.
column4: Destination signs (guide signs)
column6: Service signs
column8: Regulation signs (regulatory signs)

column2: 15. Drivers must not drive at:
column4: a speed that is greater than the posted speed limit.
column6: a speed that is greater than reasonable.
column8: a speed that is not prudent for the circumstances.

column2: 16. When driving in fog:
column4: turn on your low beams.
column6: drive the speed limit.
column8: do not drive over 10 MPH.

column2: 17. Road signs that direct drivers to services are:
column4: green and white.
column6: brown and white.
column8: blue and white.

column2: 18. To reduce their chances of colliding with an animal, drivers should:
column4: look well down the road and far off to each side.
column6: Slow down when approaching animals that are standing near the road.
column8: scan the sides of the road to watch for the reflection of vehicle headlights in the eyes of animals.

column2: 19. When you see this sign you should:
column4: slow your speed and be prepared to stop.
column6: increase your speed and try to pass other vehicles.
column8: prepare to slow down and possibly yield to oncoming traffic.
column10: slow your speed and do not pass other vehicles.

column2: 20. If an approaching driver does not dim the headlights, you should:
column4: move your eyes to the left to help avoid the glare of approaching high beams.
column6: flash your headlights to low beam for a second, then return to high beam.
column8: switch to daytime lights.
column10: flash your headlights to high beam for a second, then return to low beam.

column2: 21. If you see a “lane closed ahead” sign you should:
column4: make a U-turn. You are on the wrong side of the road.
column6: merge into the correct lane when it is safe.
column8: speed to the end of the closed lane and try to get into the other lane.

column2: 22. When you are involved in an accident where the accident scene is not readily visible to on-coming traffic, you should:
column4: let on-coming traffic watch out for themselves.
column6: let the police handle everything.
column8: have someone warn approaching traffic.

column2: 23. Following another vehicle too closely is known as:
column4: aggressive driving.
column6: speedgating.
column8: tailgating.

column2: 24. When driving at night, you should slow down and:
column4: come to a complete stop whenever there's oncoming traffic.
column6: use high beams until other drivers dim their lights.
column8: follow the vehicle ahead more closely to avoid glare from oncoming headlights.
column10: use high beams whenever possible, but never when there's oncoming traffic.

column2: 25. When a traffic signal light turns green, you should:
column4: yield the right-of-way to larger vehicles.
column6: back up slowly.
column8: yield the right-of-way to pedestrians.

column2: 26. While driving on a narrow road, you meet an oncoming vehicle. You must:
column4: make the other vehicle pull over as you were there first.
column6: pull completely off the road and stop.
column8: turn on your headlights to make sure the other vehicle sees you.
column10: allow the on-coming vehicle at least one-half of the main travelled portion of the road.

column2: 27. In case of skidding, drivers should NOT:
column4: steer the car into the direction of the skid.
column6: tap the gas pedal with their foot.
column8: pump the brakes gently if they are about to hit something.
column10: take their foot off the gas pedal.

column2: 28. Regulation signs normally are ____ rectangles with ____ letters or symbols.
column4: black; white
column6: yellow; black
column8: green; white

column2: 29. When driving in fog, drivers should:
column4: not use high beam headlights.
column6: use low beam headlights to better illuminate the road ahead.
column8: slow down and drive cautiously.

column2: 30. This road sign warns drivers that:
column4: another traffic lane joins the one they are on.
column6: left turns are not allowed at the intersection.
column8: another road enters the highway from the direction shown.
column10: the road will make a sharp turn to the right.
